message_1: How many ways are there to select 3 out of 8 distinct items, assuming that the order of selection doesn't matter?
message_2:
To find the number of ways to select 3 items out of 8 distinct items without considering the order, we can use the combination formula:

C(n, k) = n! / (k!(n-k)!)

where n is the total number of items (8 in this case), k is the number of items to select (3 in this case), and ! denotes the factorial of a number.

C(8, 3) = 8! / (3!(8-3)!)

C(8, 3) = 8! / (3!5!)

C(8, 3) = (8 × 7 × 6 × 5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1) / ((3 × 2 × 1)(5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1))

C(8, 3) = (8 × 7 × 6) / (3 × 2 × 1)

C(8, 3) = 336 / 6

C(8, 3) = 56

There are 56 ways to select 3 out of 8 distinct items without considering the order.
